metadata.title: A novel S, N dual doped carbon catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination

Table 4 Area %, Binding energy (eV) Sample Graphitic N Pyrrolic N Pyridinic N N-Carbon 54.86% (401.2) 21.04% (400.4) 24.10% (398.4) S,N-Carbon-1 55.32% (401.2) 22.13% (400.4) 22.55% (398.3) S,N-Carbon-1.5 59.63% (401.2) 23.85% (400.4) 16.52% (398.3) S,N-Carbon-2 55.05% (401.2) 25.59% (400.4) 19.35% (398.3) S,N-Carbon-2.5 52.63% (401.2) 28.07% (400.4) 19.30% (398.5) Research Paper A novel S, N dual doped carbon catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination Jian Wang a Fei Zhao a Chunli Zhang a Lihua Kang a b Mingyuan Zhu a b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University, Shihezi, Xinjiang 832000, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 PR China b Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan, Shihezi, Xinjiang 832000, PR China Key Laboratory for Green Processing of Chemical Engineering of Xinjiang Bingtuan Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University, Shihezi, Xinjiang 832000, PR China. School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 PR China Graphical abstract In this study, a sulphur and nitrogen dual-doped carbon catalyst was prepared via an easy route with p-phenyldiamine and (NH4)2S2O8 as the nitrogen and sulphur source, respectively. The obtained catalyst displayed efficient acetylene conversion for acetylene hydrochlorination, and the presence of sulphur enhanced the catalytic activity of the nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst. These catalysts show that sulphur and nitrogen have a synergistic effect for acetylene hydrochlorination. Furthermore, because of the addition of different sulphur contents, the pyrrolic N content causes certain changes in the catalysts, resulting in differences in the catalytic activity. Theoretical investigations reveal that the adsorption ability of C2H2 was enhanced by the doping of the S and N-doped carbon catalyst. This is an environmentally friendly catalyst with a broad development prospect and is cheap and easy to obtain. Keywords Metal-free catalyst Acetylene hydrochlorination Sulphur and nitrogen dual-doped carbon material Pyrrolic N 1 Introduction Acetylene hydrochlorination is one of the most important synthesis routes for the production of vinyl chloride monomers because of the special energy structure of China [1]. HgCl2 is the prominent catalyst used for this reaction; however, the evaporation of HgCl2 into the atmosphere is toxic to human beings [2]. Therefore, it is urgent and significant to find an environment friendly catalyst to replace HgCl2 catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. In the past decades, the investigation was mainly focused on exploring different metal chlorides as effective and stable catalysts for this reaction. Because of the efforts of many investigation groups, the stability of metal chlorides has been significantly enhanced. In recent years, Johnston et al. reported an increase in the life of Au-based catalysts to 3000h [3]. Au–S/N catalysts that contain little Au have shown excellent catalytic performance and stability [4]. Xu et al. synthesised a Ru catalyst with a life of approximately 50h at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 150h−1 [5]. However, because of the expense and the scarcity of Au and Ru, low-cost catalysts should be explored for acetylene hydrochlorination. In recent years, heteroatom-doped carbon has been found to be efficient at optimising catalytic performances [6–9]. N-doped carbon materials have been proven to be a low-cost, efficient, metal-free alternative to acetylene hydrochlorination [10,11]. In our previous investigation, we synthesised graphitic carbon nitride (C3N4) for acetylene hydrochlorination; this catalyst exhibited an excellent catalytic performance that is only 25% lower than that of the HgCl2 catalyst. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the carbon atom is selected to be the adsorption site for C2H2, and the nitrogen atom the adsorption site for HCl in this catalyst [2]. The activation energy of C3N4 is 77.94kcalmol−1 for acetylene hydrochlorination, which is considerably higher than that of HgCl2 (16.3kcalmol−1) [12]. Zhou et al. investigated the reaction mechanism of acetylene hydrochlorination on the surface of nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts. They reported that a nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst plays a significant role in this reaction and that the carbon atom adjacent to the nitrogen atom generates electro positivity, which can adsorb and activate acetylene. Acetylene is first adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, and then, hydrogen chloride in the gas phase reacts with the adsorbed acetylene, thereby significantly reducing the energy barrier in nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts [13]. There are three forms of nitrogen: graphitic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen and pyridinic nitrogen; finding out the type of nitrogen that plays a major role in this reaction is of great significance in the design of a non-mercy catalyst with excellent catalytic performance. Li et al. found that acetylene was very difficult to absorb on a carbon atom adjacent to graphite and pyridine nitrogen. Only carbon atoms linked with pyrrolic nitrogen can adsorb acetylene [14]. In our previous work, a boron and nitrogen heteroatom co-doped oxide graphene (B, N-G) material was synthesised; the acetylene conversion rate reached 95%, which is close to the rate of 99% of the Hg catalyst and the Au catalyst. However, B, N-G in a single catalytic activity of a catalyst on the transformation frequency is still low, only reach 15% of the Hg catalyst and 0.6% of the Au catalysts [15]. In our opinion, acetylene donates an electron to the active site of the nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst in acetylene hydrochlorination, which is very similar to oxygen adsorption in oxygen reduction reactions (ORRs). In the previous investigation, sulphur and nitrogen co-doped carbon materials were reported to display excellent ORR catalytic activity [2,16]. Therefore, we can infer that a sulphur and nitrogen co-doped catalyst may act as an excellent non-metal catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. Herein, we designed and synthesised nitrogen and sulphur dual-doped carbon, and the obtained catalysts were well characterised by a temperature-programmed decomposition (TPD) experiment. Furthermore, the influence of S on the N-doped catalyst was elucidated by DFT calculations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The sulphur and nitrogen dual-doped carbon material was synthesised using the following process: First, 6.75g of p-phenylenediamine (pPD) was evenly dispersed in a hydrochloric acid solution (0.5M, 25mL). Then, the solution was stirred below 80°C. Furthermore, the initiator (APS) was added slowly, and the resulting solution was stirred for 24h to ensure that p-phenylenediamine polymerised adequately. The crude products were washed and filtered with deionised water and dried under vacuum at 80°C for 24h. The next step of pyrolysis was performed at a heating rate ranging from 25°C to 900°C in an inert atmosphere of Ar for 175min. Then, the products were heated to 900°C for 120min. The heat-treated sample was treated with 2M H2SO4 at 80°C for 8h to wash off the inactive species from the catalysts and then thoroughly washed by deionised water and dried under vacuum at 80°C for 20h. Finally, the catalyst was heated to 900°C for 120min. The molar ratio between pPD and APS was 1:1, 1.5:1, 2:1 and 2.5:1, and the catalysts were denoted as S, N-Carbon-1; S, N-Carbon-1.5; S, N-Carbon-2 and S, N-Carbon-2.5, respectively. In order to further verify the effect of sulphur on acetylene hydrochlorination, H2O2 was used instead of APS to synthesise the catalyst, and the resulting catalyst was called N-Carbon. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface area (BET) was measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument at 77K. The sample morphology was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM2010 electron microscope testing at 200kV). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Bruker advanced D8 X-ray diffractometer using Cu-Kα irradiation (λ=1.5406Å) as the source at 40kV and 40mA in the scanning range of 2θ between 10° and 90°. Raman spectra were tested on a Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR800 using the 633nm laser excitation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of samples was analysed on the TGDSC simultaneous thermal analyzer (NETZSCH STA 449F3 Jupiter1, Germany). About 7mg of sample was used and heated to 1000°C under the air atmosphere. A Thermo Scientific TCAP 6000 Series ICP spectrometer was used to record the inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). TPD was analyzed with an AutoChem 2720 instrument (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation, USA). A DFT calculation was performed to reveal the adsorption behaviours on S, N dual doped carbon catalyst. All simulations were performed by Guassian09 software package with the hybrid density functional method M062X [17,18]. In order to obtain more accurately results, a van der Waals energy correction has been applied by using the parameters defined by Grimme et al. [19]. The cc-pVDZ basis set was applied for all atoms included C, H and Cl atoms [20,21]. This basis set has been previously applied to produce reliable results in similar system [22]. The adsorption energy of adsorbates adsorbed on catalysts were calculated as: E ads = E complex − E a d s o r b a t e s − E c a t a l y s t E ads is the adsorption energy; E complex is the total energy of adsorption complex which concluded the adsorbed adsorbates and catalysts; Eadsorbates is the total energy of isolated adsorbates; Ecatalyst is the total energy of isolated catalyst. 2.3 Catalytic reaction evaluation First, high-purity nitrogen (40mL/min) was passed through the sample at room temperature for 30min. Then, the sample was heated from room temperature to 180°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. A fixed-bed micro-reactor (diameter: 10mm) was used for analysing the activity. The temperature in this test was controlled by a CKW-1100 temperature controller. Purging by nitrogen for 30min was used to remove air present in the reactor before heated into 180°C. Acetylene (1.67mL/min, 1bar) and hydrogen chloride (1.92mL/min, 1bar) were bubbled into two mass flow controllers. Then, two types of gases were bubbled into a heated reactor containing the catalysts (1.2g, 2mL). Acetylene and hydrogen chloride were reacted to form vinyl chloride at a GHSV (C2H2) of 50h−1. The volume ratio of the feed HCl: C2H2 was 1.15:1, and the activity was tested at 180°C. Then, we used a bottle containing NaOH solution to adsorb the HCl from the gas products. The gas products were analysed online by gas chromatography (GC2014C, Shimadzu, Japan) outfitted with an FID detector. The conversion of acetylene and the selectivity to VCM as the criteria of catalytic performance were defined as following equations. C2H2 conversion=(ΦA0 −ΦA)/ΦA0 ×100% VCM selectivity=ΦVC/(1−ΦA)×100% In the equations, ΦA0 is defined as the volume fraction of acetylene in the raw gas and ΦA is defined as the volume fraction of remaining acetylene in the product gas, ΦVC is the volume fraction of vinyl chloride in product gas 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the TEM images of the sulphur and nitrogen dual-doped carbon material with different molar ratios of the pPD/APS precursors. From Fig. 1, we infer that when the molar ratio of pPD/APS is changed from 1.0 to 2.5, the lamellar distribution becomes more obvious and the surface presents a plicate morphology in the meantime. As we can see from Fig. 1d, there are more obvious folds on S, N-Carbon-2 than on the others. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the abovementioned catalysts. There are two distinct diffraction planes with peak positions at 23° and 43°, which correspond to the (002) and (101) diffraction planes of graphitic carbon [23]. The physical structure of the catalyst was investigated by BET experiments. A nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm was used for determining the surface area, the pore volume, and the bore diameter of these catalysts. As seen from Table 1 , an increase in the molar ratio from 1.0 to 2.5 between pPD and APS did not significantly change the BET surfaces and the pore volumes, but the bore diameter gradually increased from 2.82 to 7.01nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed to analyse the content and the ratio of N/S; the results are presented in Table 2 . With an increase in the ratio of pPD to APS, the N content increased from 6.08% to 7.91% and the S content decreased from 6.98% to 2.69%. When the ratio of pPD to APS was 2:1, the N content was 7.78% and the S content was 3.58%. The abovementioned data show that sulphur and nitrogen were successfully embedded into the framework of the sulphur and nitrogen co-doped catalyst. We also tested several metal elements content such as Fe, Cu, Zn, K and Al, and the results were listed in Table 3 . No obvious metal element presented in those catalysts, indicating that the catalytic performance can not be affected by metal in the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3 A, the acetylene conversion increased from 47.57% to 82.44% when the molar ratio between pPD and APS increased from 1.0 to 2.0. The S, N-Carbon-2 catalyst showed the best catalytic performance for acetylene hydrochlorination, which reached 82.44%. The acetylene conversion only reduced by approximately 5.3% after 9h of reaction. As for the S, N-Carbon-2.5, the initial catalytic activity reached 82.36%, but the deactivation rate was faster than that of the others; thus, the acetylene conversion reached 68.19% after 9h of reaction. This indicated that the acetylene conversion and the stability improved to a certain extent with an increase in the molar ratio of pPD to APS from 1.0 to 2.0. However, beyond a certain range, the stability of these catalysts decreased, but the S, N-Carbon showed superior stability and activity than our recent work, the catalytic activity of S, N-Carbon-2 reached to 82.44%, which was higher than our recent research work (Co-N-AC catalyst, 36h−1, 65%) [24]. In order to further investigate the effect of S atoms on acetylene hydrochlorination, we used H2O2 instead of APS to synthesise the N-Carbon catalyst without sulphur atoms. As shown in Fig. 3A, N-Carbon has a certain catalytic activity but it is considerably less than that of the other catalysts that contain sulphur. N-Carbon also showed a certain degree of stability and catalytic activity. As Fig. 3B shown, the selectivity of VCM maintains at above 99.5%. The catalytic activity of the catalyst further improved with S atoms and N atoms; therefore, there was a synergistic effect between S atoms and N atoms with respect to acetylene hydrochlorination. In the next set of steps, XPS was used for analysing the content of an element in a catalyst. The binding energies at 284.5 and 532eV were attributed to the spectrum of C 1s and O 1s, and the binding energy of the N 1s spectrum was approximately at 400eV [25]. In the meantime, sulphur could be scanned from the wide XPS spectrum, and the binding energies at 164.2 and 169.9eV were attributed to the spectrum of S2s and S2p, respectively [26]. The above data also showed that sulphur and nitrogen were successfully embedded into the catalyst framework. Three types of nitrogen species at 398.6±0.3, 400.4 and 401.2eV are presented in Fig. 4 (A–E). Table 4 presents the content changes for three genres of nitrogen species [27,28]. As shown in Table 4, the content of pyrrolic N varies with the sulphur content. Controlling the molar ratio of pPD and APS can increase the content of pyrrolic N from 21.04% to 28.07%; the contents of graphitic N and pyridinic N change irregularly. Therefore, the catalytic activity of the catalysts was different; this is consistent with the results of previous research [14]. In the case of S, N-Carbon-2, as we can see from Fig. 3, the catalytic activity was the best. Catalysts showed a better catalytic activity and stability when the N/S ratio was 2:1 for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. As for N-Carbon, no matter the stability, the activity was bad. This illustrated that there was a synergistic effect between S atoms and N atoms for acetylene hydrochlorination. Fig. 5 shows the N/S ratio, pyrrolic N content and the catalytic activity per unit surface area (10−3 g/m2). As shown in Fig. 5A and B, with an increase in the ratio of pPD to APS, the N/S ratio increased. Meanwhile, an increase in the pyrrolic N content led to an increase in the conversion per unit specific surface area. However, the acetylene conversion of S, N-Carbon-2.5 decreased; this could be attributed to the fact that the BET surface of the S, N-Carbon-2.5 catalyst became smaller but still had the best acetylene conversion per unit specific surface area. When the molar ratio of pPD/APS increased sequentially, the catalytic activity decreased. This illustrated that the N/S ratio was inversely proportional to the catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination. Further, there was an optimal ratio for the synergistic effect of N/S. XPS spectra showed that the relative content ratio of N to S was 2.173:1. Raman spectra (Fig. 6 ) was used to analyse graphitization degree of N-Carbon and S, N-Carbon-2, and the ID/IG ratio (1.14) of S, N-Carbon-2 was less than that of N-Carbon(1.27). It indicated that the graphitization degree increased after sulphur doping. Then, the TPD of C2H2 was performed for further study to analyse the role of the abovementioned catalysts. Here we selected two types of catalysts (S, N-Carbon-2 and N-Carbon) to explore the differences between an N-doped catalyst and a S, N dual-doped catalyst. The peak area of C2H2 was used for determining the adsorption amount of C2H2, and the temperature of desorption was used for calculating the adsorption strength. Fig. 7 shows that the catalysts had distinct adsorption for acetylene, and the peak area of S, N-Carbon-2 was far greater than that of N-Carbon. At the same time, the binding strength (198.4°C) of C2H2 with S, N-Carbon-2 was also stronger than that of N-Carbon (155.9°C). The abovementioned results implied that the addition of sulphur increased the adsorption strength of C2H2; this result is consistent with that of the catalytic activity of the considered catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1. TGA analysis was used to clarify the reason for the deactivation of those catalysts. Fig. 8 shows mass loss of fresh and spent catalysts under an oxygen atmosphere, the mass loss of used catalysts was higher than the fresh catalyst. It shows that coke occurred on these two catalysts in acetylene hydrochorination. Therefore, coke deposition may be the reason for the deactivation of the catalyst. DFT calculations were performed to display the enhanced adsorption ability of C2H2 on the S, N-Carbon catalysts. The models we employed were displayed in Fig. 9 , which displayed the most stable optimized structures of the N-doped and S, N dual-doped carbon catalysts. Fig. 10 shows the changes in the adsorption energies between N-Carbon and S, N-Carbon. The corresponding most stable adsorption structures are shown in Fig. 11 . For the three types of N-species catalysts (pyrrolic N, pyridinic N and graphitic N), C2H2 was slightly adsorbed. The adsorption energies (Eads) of C2H2 on these three types of catalysts were −3.57, −4.48 and −5.1kcal/mol. After the doping of the S species, the adsorption ability of C2H2 on S, N-Carbon catalysts significantly enhanced. Furthermore, Eads increased to −32.91, −18.62 and −5.81kcal/mol. These results revealed that S-N co-doping can significantly enhance the adsorption of C2H2. Notably, the S-pyrrolic N co-doping dominated the adsorption of C2H2. TPD was performed to directly compare the adsorption abilities of C2H2 between the N-Carbon and the S, N-Carbon catalysts. The desorption temperature in the TPD profiles reflected the binding strength of the adsorbed species with the material surface. Fig. 10 shows that the binding strength of the adsorbates on the N-doped catalysts increased considerably after the doping of S atoms. 4 Conclusions In this study, S, N dual-doped carbon catalysts were prepared and applied to acetylene hydrochlorination. These catalysts showed excellent catalytic stability and activity for acetylene hydrochlorination. The catalytic efficiency of a unit surface area was promoted with an increase in the content of pyrrolic N. Furthermore, the addition of different sulphur contents changed the content of pyrrolic N in the catalysts. S, N dual-doped catalysts had obviously enhanced adsorption ability, which was proven by DFT calculations and TPD experiments. In summary, there is a synergistic effect between S atoms and N atoms with respect to acetylene hydrochlorination. This method offers a new approach to control pyrrolic nitrogen content, and research on acetylene hydrogen chloride is very significant. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a sulphur and nitrogen dual-doped carbon catalyst was prepared via an easy route with p-phenyldiamine and (NH4)2S2O8 as the nitrogen and sulphur source, respectively. The obtained catalyst displayed efficient acetylene conversion for acetylene hydrochlorination, and the presence of sulphur enhanced the catalytic activity of the nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst. These catalysts show that sulphur and nitrogen have a synergistic effect for acetylene hydrochlorination. Furthermore, because of the addition of different sulphur contents, the pyrrolic N content causes certain changes in the catalysts, resulting in differences in the catalytic activity. Theoretical investigations reveal that the adsorption ability of C2H2 was enhanced by the doping of the S and N-doped carbon catalyst. This is an environmentally friendly catalyst with a broad development prospect and is cheap and easy to obtain.
coredata.dc:title: A novel S, N dual doped carbon catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination

dcterms:subject.$: Sulphur and nitrogen dual-doped carbon material
